sp.p: This is a hearing of a Duel indeed,—Files Ha, ha, ha, you was reſolv'd to prevent Murder; you need never fear the Exaltation of the Gallows, for your Courage reaches but to a Chance Medly at moſt.

sp.speaker: C. Man,
sp.p: Prethee who were thoſe Gentlemen Sir William, methinks they us'd you very familiarly.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Men of no Honour you may conclude Collonel, elſe they would not have abus'd Gentlemen, when they was defenceleſs.

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: Right, but why wou'd you be defenceleſs? Faith Sir William if this News reaches your Miſtreſs's Ears, it will ruin you in her Favour. Take this for a Rule, the leſs regard you have for your Honour the more you ſink in the Eſteem of your Miſtreſs, for all Women hate a Coward; you ought to be forbid the Habits of Men, who can be guilty of Eſſeminency that even Women would bluſh at.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, I think Paſſive Valour ſits well enough upon Men that have Eſtates, and have a Mind to live and enjoy them.

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: Damn him for a Cowardly Blockhead; prethee lets go, I'm ſick of their Folly; beſides you ſaid you would convince me of Clarinda's Falſhood.

div.stage: Enter Bellmein's Man, and gives him a Letter.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I have run Sir all the way, for the Porter told me it muſt be given to you that Moment.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Ha! There's a lucky hit Collonel; ſhe Invites me to come to her Lodging, and her Servant ſhould be ready to convey me into her Apartment. Here read it Man, now you may convince your ſelf.—Egad if I were not a damn'd Honeſt Fellow to my Friend, now cou'd I paſs three hours the moſt agreeably in the World. Pox on me for a prating Coxcomb, could not I have held my Tougue. VVell what think you of it Collonel?

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p:
It is not her Hand, but that's nothing, ſhe might diſguiſe that to conceal it from me. I know not what to think,
but I'm reſolv'd to go, and if I find her falſe 'twill cure me effectually.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Come on then

sp.speaker: Ogle.
sp.p: I have been conſidering all this while upon what the Collonel ſaid, and I am reſolv'd to be Valiant; for if Ladies don't like a Coward—I ſhall never get a Fortune; for ought I know I may Fight as well as any Body, I'm reſolv'd I'll try. Harkee Sr. William, our Servants are here by, let's ſend for our Swords and fight in Earneſt.

sp.speaker: Sir. Will.
sp.p: Not I Mr. Ogle, I declare againſt Fighting poſitively.

sp.speaker: Ogle.
sp.p: But I declare for Fighting, and ſo ſhall you, or reſign all Pretenſions to Clarinda, for I deſign to Marry her my ſelf, therefore don't think of her, do you hear.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You Marry her, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ogle.
sp.p: 'Zounds Sir, dare you laugh at a Gentleman, you dare not Fight, take that Sir (Strikes up his Heels) and the next time I hear you ſpeak a Word more of her, I'll cut your Throat, and ſo good by.—So, this is one ſtep towards Courage; I am reſolv'd to Challenge every Man that pretends to a Fortune, till I have got one my ſelf; and now my Hand's in, I'll Challenge this Collonel the next time. I ſee him, though at the Head of his Regiment.

l.hi: I'll Cut and Slaſt, and Kill to that Degree,
I'll crowd up Hell till there's no Room for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Rat this Blockhead, what a Metamorphoſis is here; 'tis well I fell upon my Cloak, or I had daub'd all my Cloaths, Bliſter me, Well, to ſing, dance, or Court a Lady, or any ſuch Gentieman-like Employments I'll turn my Back of none; but for this ſlovenly Exerciſe of Fighting, I ſhall never be brought to endure, impair my Vigour.

div.stage: Carefull pulling in Emilia in Boys Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: WHo the Devil have we here? Nay, nay Sir, I muſt ſee your Face; another Gallant of my Daughter's I warrant! Who are you Sir, from whence come you, what Buſineſs have you in my Houſe, ha?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh Lord, what ſhall I ſay to this old Fellow, he'll certainly know me.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: What are you ſtudying for a Lye Sir? Adod I ſhall make you find your Tongue, ſpeak quickly or I'll cut your Throat (Draws.) you Dog you.
Ah! Oh Lord a Sword! For Heavens ſake Sir, Oh Lord Sir don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Know you Sir? who the Pox are you Sir, ha? Emilia, why what Maſquerade's this? VVhere's my Daughter.
Ho Sir, your Humble Servant, why what a Pox are you going into the Service; you are two pretty Volunteers faith.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha! my Father, what ſhall I ſay,—I'll e'en face it out ſince he has catc'd me; we have done a Friend of yours ſome Service Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A Friend of mine! As how, pray forſooth?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why you muſt know Sir I was inform'd of a Duel between Sir William Mode, and a Brother Beau of his; the concern I knew you had for Sir William's ſafety, engag'd my Care for the Prevention; I was unwilling to Expoſe him, by ſending any body elſe, ſo that my Couſin and I, by the help of this Diſguiſe, pa • ted them; but we ſhou'd not need to have made ſuch haſte, for the Puppits was trying their Valour ſafely with a couple of Files, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, And this was the occaſion of your being in Breeches, ha?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And I think it a good project too Uncle.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: You do,—Well Daughter pray let's have you in your Feminine Capacity again; for though you Bully in Breeches, I hope you'll Marry in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: Marry Sir!

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Yes forſooth, I have ſent for Sir William, in order to have the ſettlement compleated to Night, and to Morrow your Honour ſhall riſe with the Sun; that is to ſay, you ſhall be my Lady Mode.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Honour Sir, where's the Honour of ſuch a Husband? I hope Sir you will not Marry me to a Coward; why there's not a needy Bully about Town but will beat a Maintenance out of him, and where is the Reputation of ſuch a Marriage.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: But he'll make a ſwinging Jointure, and if you don't like him when you have him, you may live apart.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Heaven what ſhall I ſay,—Sir I beg you but delay your purpoſe for a Month.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Not for a Day.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir I have ſworn not to Marry this Month.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Have you ſo, pray who have you ſwora to Miſtreſs, to Mr. Ogle, ha?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ogle, who is he pray Sir?—Heaven, has my Father got this Story too!

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You don't know ſuch a Perſon I'll warrant you as Mr. Ogle?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I have ſeen ſuch a Fellow Sir, but never ſpoke to him.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: No—look in my Face,—You never ſpoke to him, that is, encourag'd his Love?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: No—Upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: —You lie, you have no Honour, read that, (throws her the Letter) and do you hear, reſolve to marry Sir William to morrow Morning by ſix, or I'll Marry my ſelf before Twelve; ſo take your choice. I'll Ogle you, and Soldier you with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Impudence from Ogle, I'll have the Raſcal toſt in a Blanket; ſee Emilia what an audacious Letter tis, bleſs me, I have no Patience; I encourage ſuch a Raſcal.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: He is very familiar methinks—hang him, the Fool's below your Anger, never think on't; come prethee think which way to turn your ſelf if the Colionel be falſe, as I dare ſwear he is. What think you of Marrying Sir William, he is Maſter of a fair Eſtate, which you may make ſubſervient to your Pleaſures, to makē Life's rugged Journey paſs the ſmoother. If he be true, as you have but little reaſon to think he is, you may yet find ſome way to accompliſh your deſires. Come the time draws on in which you'll be convinc'd of his Truth or Falſhhood.

l.hi: Come what will, reſolve to be content,
And truſt to Fortune for the wiſh'd Event.

div.stage: Enter Careful, Toper, and Mrs. Plotwell, dreſt like a Quaker.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mr. Toper, Your Couſin is welcome, my Houſe is at your Service Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I thank thee, but pray thee do not Madam me, my name is Anne.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A very handſome VVomand, and very modeſtly dreſt.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I have us'd all the Arguments in my Power to Convert her from this Formality, but in vain, ſhe's as averſe to the Faſhions, as other VVomen are fond of 'em; but I hope your Neice and Daughter will work a Reformation in her.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: I rather hope ſhe'll work one in them, I'll aſſure you I'll recommend her as a Patron. Is this the woman you would recommend to me for a VVife Mr. Toper.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: The ſame Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: I proteſt I like her exceedingly ſhe ſeems, cut out on purpoſe for me; her plain way of Living will improve my Eſtate, and her Morals will hamper my Daughter, I like a Religious Woman.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: You can't be better match'd, if ſhe has not too much; yeſterday I carried her to wait on a Relation of ours that has a Parrot, and whilſt I was diſcourſing about ſome private Buſineſs, ſhe converted the Bird, and now it talks of nothing but the Light of the Spirit, and the inward Man. Ha, ha. Caref. Good lack, good lack.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Well, well, thee wilt never leave thy rediculous Jeſts; I ſay that Mankind were not made for Foppery and Pride, but to do good in their Generation,—Prethee ſhew me one Text of Scripture for the Faſhions, or where Jewels are commanded, or what Holy Matron ever had a Valet, to dreſs 'em, as they ſay the French Ladies have, Oh monſtrous Faſhion!—No no, our devouteſt Women wore courſe Linnen, or rather none at all.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ay, ſuch Saints as wore their Congregations without ſide, and ſwarm'd with Chriſtian Vermin, it muſt be them, ha, ha, ha, but you hold every handſome Garment a Sin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Handſome Garment! Verily I believe, if we are puniſh'd with Taxes again to carry on another War, 'twill be a juſt Judgment upon this ſinful Land for their full Wiggs, Favourites, Furbelows, falſe Teeth, and Patches.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Truly I'm of her opinion, ſhe ſpeaks like an Oracle, for the Devil was never ſo Proud as our Women are now a days, (Aſide.) I am reſolv'd, if my Daughter ſhew the leaſt relunctance to my will, to Marry her out of hand. I'll motion it to her, and try how ſhe likes me.— (aſide.) What think you of a Husband forſooth, for to be plain with you, your extraordinary qualities have rais'd a great deſire in me of becoming ſuch.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I doubt Friend thoul't expect a larger Fortune than I am Dame of.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I proteſt I don't care if you have not a Groat, your Vertue's a wealthy Dowry to me, ſay you'll but have me, and 'tis enough;

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: But it may be thou'lt be againſt my courſe of Life; I love Retirement, muſt have time for my Devotion in my own way; I'm not us'd to the Ceremony of Viſits, and hate Tea-Table Vanity, and Card-play, as they call it. Toper. Our Plot takes rarely. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: This makes me love you the more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: One thing more; Thou haſt a Daughter they ſay, a topping Gallant, which I deſire to ſee, and try if good Admonitions, together with Example, wont reform her; for plainly I dont care to come under the Roof where Children are, if they be not dutiful, ſo that I muſt ſee her firſt e're I can give thee my Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: That you ſhall preſently—Here carry this Gentlewoman to my Daughter and tell her, ſhe muſt entertain her as her Mother that is to be, tell her ſo from me, d'ye hear.
Really Mr. Toper, Your Couſin is a profound Chriſtian, if my Daughter refuſe to Marry Sir William,—I'll Jointure her in my whole Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: For ought I know, You can't do better than Marry; for who who would be plagu'd with a diſobedient Child?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Eſpecially when they depend upon us for their Fortunes, the Devil a Young Fellow would care a Souce for their Perſons, did not our Purſe-ſtrings draw. Here forſooth my Daughter is running mad after a Soldier, a Fellow whoſe Fortunes depend upon his Sword, and here we are going to Wars again, and ſix to four but a Cannon-Bullet takes his Head off, and then the Wife is turn'd home to her Father again, and in ſuch Caſes a Father has never diſpos'd of his Children entirely, and all the Jointure ſhee'll bring, will conſiſt of Houſings, Holſter-Caps, Piſtols, and Swords.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's Sir William Mode below Sir.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Tell him I'll wait on him preſently. Come Mr. Toper, you ſhall be witneſs of our Agreement; I ſent for him to compleat the Buſineſs, Sign Seal to Night, and to Morrow we'll have a Dance.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I fancy we ſhall drive Dancing out of your Head, Old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: WEll, in my Conſcience the firſt ſight of you frighted me horribly, though I knew your Plot, I vow you make a ſanctified Figure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Might I paſs upon the Brethren think you?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ay, and hold forth too I'll warrant you, without being diſcover'd. But is my Uncle ſo hot upon Matrimony ſay you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: As a hound upon the Scent, tho' he'll ſhare no more of the Pleaſure, than the Dog of the Game he runs down, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I vow I can't help laughing to think what a trick we ſhall put upon him,—but the duce on't I cannot be heartily merry till I ſe • Event of this Meeting; I long till the Collonel comes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: So do I as much as you, to upbraid him with his Treachery.
In my Conſcience he's here,—ſhow him into my Chamber, tell him Ill wait on him preſently,—Now Clarinda you ſhall go in myplace.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Heaven! how I tremble. Oh the Perfidious Wreteh, ſure he's
quite loſt to Vertue, that he dares thus impudently venture into the very Houſe. Oh give me Patience Heaven, and Power to back my Reſolution, and Scorn enough to ſhow my deep Reſentment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I'll to the Old Man, and keep him in Diſcourſe, that he mayn't interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Do ſo,—I muſt liſten a little to hear what Reception ſhe gives him.

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: This Love makes Men the Erranteſt Aſſes in the World, what bluſtering Mars with all his Steely Garranture of War cou'd never do, this blind Boy does with a Feather'd Reed. Oh my Soul, I think I'm grown a Coward, and begin to fear, my Heart beats faſter than a Raw Soldier's in his firſt Engagement, or a Longing Maid in the Arms of a Man ſhe likes, when Opportunity makes her. Fear. Sure it cannot be Clarinda.
Ha! By Heaven the very Crocodile. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: By all my hopes of Happineſs the very Monſter. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: Madam, you are ſurpriz'd I believe, not to meet the Man you expected; I beg your Pardon for this Diſappointment.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh. Indignation! No Sir I have met the Man I expected, though you are diſappointed in your Woman.

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: What does ſhe mean!—Have you a Stratagem Madam, to bring you off,—come Ill help you; ſay, you happen'd into this Room by chance, and had no knowledge of the Plot, expected no Gallant.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh unheard of Impudence! a Gallant! No thou Monſter of Ingratitude; have I refus'd all Mankind for thee? Nay, broke in upon the Rules of my Obedience, that I might keep my Faith Inviolate, and am I thus Rewarded? Is it not enough that you are Falſe, and that I ſee you ſo, but you muſt add to your Barbarity, and throw a Scandal on my Fame, to hide your baſe Proceeding. Marry thee, No! From this Moment I reſolve to hate thee, and to put it out of thy Power ever to deceive me a ſecond time I'll Marry. Inſtantly. (Bellmein Peeping.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: I muſt hear how the Collonel ſucceeds in my Place.—

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: It is enough I know thee guilty of that very Crime thou would'ſt impoſe on me; know that you writ to my Friend to come here with whom you have had many private Conferences, tho' I, Heaven knows, would not believe it, till my Eyes convinc'd me; but now thy Crimes are obvious to my Sight, and I take thee at thy word, and from this Moment I'll never ſee you more: Confuſion on your Sex.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha, his Friend! what can he mean,—ſure there's ſome Miſtake in this, yet I cannot call him back.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What have we Eves-droppers;—Oh Heavens! why was not you with my Couſin?

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Hey day! why was not you with the Collonel?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Why, are not you the Collonel?

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: No faith, and now I begin to ſuſpect you are not Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: you are in the Right indeed, I am not.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Heavens I'm undone, Manly's innocent.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: No, no Madam, I'll call my Friend back immediately, he ſhall beg Pardon upon the Spot,—Why, what a damn'd Miſtake is here; faith he's gone, but here's an old Gentleman coming up.
sp.stage: [Goes to the Door, and returns quickly,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Lord, my Father, I'm undone if he finds a Man here; what ſhall I do? This was your Project, Emilia.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Ha! 'Zdeath Madam where ſhall I run? For methinks I would not do any more Miſchief, what ſhall I do Ladies?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ha, a lucky thought comes into my Head; here, here, here, lie down upon this Mat.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: With all my Heart: Pox on't, to be thus put to't for nothing. If I had but got a Maidenhead, or made a Cuckold, it would not have vext me.
sp.stage: (Lies down, and they rowl him up.

div.stage: Enter Careful, and tumbles over the Mat.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: There, there, lye ſtill.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A Pox on your Pride, we muſt have Matts with a Vengeance, but I'll turn over a new Leaf with this Houſe I'll warrant you; I'll have no Matts, but ſuch as lie under the Feather-Beds: Here I might have broke my Neck.
Toby, Sirrah, remove that Matt, and do you hear, throw it into the Horſe-Pond; I'll have no more Mats in my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Matt, 'tis damn'd heavy; come out here, I believe the Dog is got into it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Lord, what ſhall I do? (aſide.
sp.stage: [The Man goes to take up the Matt, and finds it heavy, ſhakes it and out drops Belimein.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: The Horſe-pond! Nay then 'tis time to ſhift for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Here, here, There's a Guinea for you Toby, bring him off ſome way or other.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Ha, what was that?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Bark Sir, bark; only the great Dog Sir was crept in the Matt.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Wough, wough, wough, wough.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Rarely done; expect a better Reward for this, Toby.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: The Dog was it, I proteſt I thought it had been a Thief.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No Sir, nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why how now! Methinks you are mightily prink'd up. Mercy upon me, what a Buſh of Hair is there fruz'd out; in my Conſcience I believe you have got the Fore-top of ſome Beau's Wigg.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: That's the Faſhion Uncle, you wou'd not have us dreſs like my Quaking Aunt that is to be. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: How now Sauce-box, your Quaking Aunt quotha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you don't deſign to Marry that thing.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Thing do you call her? Icod you ſhall Marry Sir William immediately, or call that thing Mother, I can tell you, that.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Heaven, what ſhall I do?

div.stage: Enter Sir William, and Mrs. Plotwell.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Here Sir William, I give her to your Arms; I'll have my Coach harneſs'd, and to Church this Moment.

sp.speaker: Sir. Will.
sp.p: Madam tho' I don't pretend to be a Beau, yet I hope the World will diſtinguiſh the difference between a rough, unhewn Soldier, and a polliſh'd Gentleman; I don't, in the leaſt, hint at Manly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Inſipid Coxcomb. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: to Plot. For Heavens ſake invent ſome way to give her an Hours time to conſider, or ſhe's undone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Friend ſhall I ſpeak one word with thee.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Twenty if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Let me adviſe thee, do not be ſo paſſionate with thy Daughter, the little Diſcourſe I had with her, ſhew'd her to be tractable; if thou think'ſt ſit, Ill read her t'other Leſſon upon her Duty, and I don't doubt but ſhe'll comply.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: With all my Heart; for whatever thou ſay'ſt, muſt be for her good, I'm convinc'd. Sir William we'll go take a Glaſs in the next Room till the Bride be ready, and then—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And then Madam I ſhall be the happieſt Man alive; if I would change conditions with the Czar of Muſcovy, may I be Condemn'd to the Smoak of Tobacco, and never know the Pleaſure of taking Snuff.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A very Courtly Wiſh indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Come, don't trifle away the time I have given you, but write to Manly, and beg him to Protect you, and Reſcue you from the Arms of this Fool.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh how can I write to him, whom I have abus'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: And did not he pay you in the ſame Coin! Come, come, this little Miſtake rather ſerves to encreaſe his Love than diminiſh it, when he finds you true, as no doubt but Bellmein has told him e're this, he'll be glad to accept the Conditions. Come, come, write to him Toper is within, and he ſhall carry it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, it being my laſt Shift, I'll follow your Advice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Ay, ay, do ſo, I'll warrant you a Fortune, and the O • d Man's Conſent before I have done with him.

div.stage: A Drum beating up for Volunteers. Bellmein croſſes the Stage, and a Serjeant after him.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Captain, Captain.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Ha, Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I have got the fineſt Volunteer, a Beau, Captain.

sp.speaker: C. Cap.
sp.p: A Beau! Nay, if the Beaus begin to Liſt, let the French look to't. Where is he Serjeant?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: He's coming Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: I can't ſtay now, but I'll be here in a Moment, and I'll bring the Collonel with me.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: 'll wait you here Sir.
The Captain will be here in a Moment Sir; but pray Sir why will you go for a Soldier, Methinks you might get a Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Becauſe I dreamt Sir I ſhould be a General,—and I have a a mind to riſe gradually, I hate Jumping into Honour at once.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Sir I honour you; no doubt but you Dream will come true.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Sir I dreamt laſt Night that I ſaw two Armys join Battle, and m • thought • n the Scuffle my Brains was knock'd out, and when I'wak'd, I wonder'd to find my ſelf with all my Limbs, I ſtraight felt for my other Leg, and ſuſpected my Eyes when they inform'd me I had both Hands.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: A very good Dream, and ſignifies your Advancement.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Nay, after that I had the ſtrangeſt Dream, my Man found me Scaling my Curtains for a Fort, killing my Pillow, and entring Duel with my Breeches. Methought all the Trojan Faces in the Hangings were turn'd Frenchmen, and a Famine raging amongſt 'em, they reſolv'd to Eat me; ſo caſting Dice what part of me to devour firſt, the • ot fell upon my Head. Now Sir, all theſe Dreams I interpret quite contrary, I know I ſhall be a great Man.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: No, doubt on't Sir—I'm afraid all this Fellow's Courage lies in his Sleep. I'm reſolv'd to ſound him a little. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Prithee, Serjeant, tell me, what ſort of a Thing a Camp is?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p:
Why truly Sir, a Camp wou'd be a pleaſant place, did the Fields produce Feather-beds; or if the Streams like thoſe of the Golden Age! did run pure Wine; Or if Camp Meals wou • d 〈◊〉 Twelve and Seven obſerve due Hours!—But, Sir, 〈…〉 ſtarv'd on ſcarce freſh Green Sword, juſt ſo much Earth, to 〈…〉 then to live the Life of Nature; Or as ſome do call it, The Life of the Hardy, to quench one's Thirſt at the next Spring, 〈◊〉 up one's ſelf each Night in Turff, and thence come ſorth, like one of 〈◊〉 Soldiers, ſown of Serpents Teeth, and 〈…〉 Furrow, is a Courſe of Life, I fear, will never ſuit with your •••
ſtitution.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: 'Tis ſomething hard truly, but no matter, I'm reſolv • d.

sp.speaker: S •• j.
sp.p: Oh! This is nothing Sir; here comes on a Troop, and you in Honour can't but loſe an Eye; an Engine there goes off, and you will ſhow your ſelf a Coward, unleſs you loſe an Arm—Here you are ſurrounded, and then 'twere baſe to bring more than one Sholder off.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: [Rubbing his Shoulder.] Ha! I don't like it. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Nay Sir, conſider ere you go—For 'tis a danm'd Diſcredit to have a Noſe after a Battle, or to walk the Streets upon your own Legs.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Humph!—I feel my ſelf already partly compos'd of Fleſh, partly of Wood. Methinks, I hang between two Crutches, like a Man in Chains, toſt by the Wind, I don't like this Sli • ing into Reputation.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But theſe Men that you raiſe Serjeant, Are they to go againſt the French or Spaniards?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Why do you aſk Sir?

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Becauſe I cannot in Honour draw my Sword againſt the French.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: How ſo, pray? You're no Jacobite, I hope.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p:
Oh! Sir, my Scruples are not founded upon Religion; but I'll tell you, the laſt Long Vacation, I made the Tour of Paris, where I receiv'd ſuch extraordinary Marks of Civility from the French Court, particularly from the Duke of Berry, the Duke of Burgundy and the Duke—and from the Governour of Callis, ſuch extravagant Obligations; But above all, from the Governour's Daughter—That upon my Soul, I cannot deſcend ſo far from the Punctilio's of
Honour, to go againſt 'em; But againſt Spain, I—Ha! the Coll. I'm reſolv'd to fight him however, Death, Hell and Furies: Draw Sir!

sp.speaker: C • ll.
sp.p: That I ſhou'd be ſuch a Sot to believe her falſe. Oh! I'm undone, ruin'd beyond retrieving!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Draw Sir, For what, Sir? [To Bell.]

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Sir, I ſay Draw Sir, or elſe reſign all Pretenſions to Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why what a Metamorphus is this? Is this your Voluntier, Serjant?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but if you had not come as you did, he had been gone, for I found his Courage began to ſink.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: To Clarinda! How dares ſuch a Coxcomb as you Name Clarinda? [Draws and Diſarms him.] Now learn more Wit, or get more Courage.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Courage, Sir, Z'death, Sir, I'll Box with you, [Pulling off his Neckcloth.] you have got my Sword, but no matter for that, I ll Fight it out at Fiſts; Loſe a Fortune for want of Fighting, No!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I'll Box you, you Dog; give me the Cane, [To the Serjant.] Sirrah, I'll make Mummy of your Bones, I'll make you forſwear ſauntering after Fortunes, nay you ſhall not dare to look towards the Houſe where they live, or ſo much as think of them.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Oh Lord Sir, for Heaven's ſake! Sir, I'll obſerve the Conditions.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay now you are too rigid, I dare promiſe for Mr. Ogle.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: I will indeed Sir, only let me think of them, for who can help thinking, Sir—

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: No, here Serjeant, take this Fellow, and let him run the Gauntlet, I'll think you Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Oh Lord Sir! ſpare that, and I will not think of 'em upon my Faith, Sir.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Nay one thing more you muſt promiſe, which is, to reſume your w • nted Cowardice, and betake you to your Deſk again. Go take Money of the Men you mean to Cozen; talk little, except when you are paid for't, 'tis an Antidote againſt Beating; keep your Hand from your Sword, and your Landreſſes Petticoats, and you'll live at peace.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p:
I will Collonel—Give me Wiſdom that is beaten into a Man, for that ſticks to him Egad. I'm wiſer than a Juſtice of Peace; your Precepts are very learned, Sir. I'm your humble Serva • t—Farewel Sword, and welcom Tongue again. Now can't I
poſitively tell, whether 'tis beſt to be Couragious, or to have no Courage at all; Beaten if I Fight, and Beaten if I do not.—Now I think I know ſomething of the Law, and yet if the Queſtion was put to me I cou'd not Reſolve it,

l.hi: But for my own part, I'll lay Courage down,
As all Men do, when they take up the Gown;
Cloak'd with the Law, I may ſecurely • aul,
And he that dares Affront me then, ſhall pay for all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

div.stage: [Enter Toper, and gives the Coll. a Letter.]

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ha! Coll. Opportunly met, I bring an Expreſs from the Queen of Beauty; her Orders are in that Paper.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Ha! 'Tis Clarindas hand— (reads) I hope by this time, you are ſatisfied of my Innocence, as I'm of yours; if not, I beg of you, by all the Tyes of Honour, to reſcue me from this fooliſh Knight, to whom I am this Moment to be married by the rigid Command of my barbarous Father; and if I don't clear your Cenſures, uſe me as you pleaſe. Yours Clairnda—Reſcue thee yes, the Fool ſhall quit all Pretenſions to thee, unleſs this Arm deceive me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If it does Boy, here's another at thy Service.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: You may ſeiſe her at the End of the Street as ſhe paſſes; Be ſure you marry her as ſoon as you have got her; Let me alone to bring her Fortune, the Captain muſt help our Plot forward, as ſoon as he has help'd you, away with her—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With all my Heart, I love Miſchief; I have a plaguy hankering Mind after this Couſin tho', e're ſince Manly told me ſhe has Ten Thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: The Yoak ſhou'd be well lin'd, or 'twill ſit very uneaſy at beſt.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, there muſt be Gold proportionable to the Alloy, or 'twou'd not be current Coin, Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Well, I'm a good Natur'd Fellow now, to ſpend my time in your Buſineſs when I have an Aſſignation with one of the prettieſt Girls about Town, Faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Some old o're worn Drab, I'll warrant, caſt off by all the Beaus in Town, and now is become a new Face to the Drunkards.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: No Faith, ſhe's a kept Miſtriſs, ſhe Coſt me not a Souce.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p:
Thou art ſtill labouring between two Tides, Wine and Women:
Wilt thou never take up till thou art confin'd by a Doctor to dry Diet.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Dry Diet? You don't mean a Wife, I hope, catch me at that Meat and Choke me with it, that's juſt a Confinement to Sea-Biſ • uet at Land; tho' I'd do you all the Service I can, Collonel, in helping you to your Miſtriſs, yet I can't help lamenting the loſs of a Friend.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Why will Matrimony loſe me to my Friends? I ſhall love them as well as ever, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ay, but your Friends won't care that for you, [Snaping his Fingers.] for e're the ſecond Bottle, you'll be calling, What's to pay? Your Wife won't go to Bed till you come Home; this makes Company uneaſy, and what makes us uneaſy decreaſes our Value for • t; For my Part, I had rather be confin'd to Sea-Men in a Storm, or the Cant of a Conventicle, than the Company of a Married Man, for at every Mouſe ſtirring, I ſhou'd think the Comforts of Matrimony was coming, with all its Commanding Retinue; A Wife, Egad I'd want Wine, the only Support of this Body.—

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Well, you declare for a Bottle, I for a Wife, which I think the greater pleaſure far.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Where ſhall we find you?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: At the Roſe.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Adieu, Belmein ſhall come to you there.

l.hi: Let Fools be fetter'd to that Clog, a Wife,
Whilſt free, I reap the Pleaſure of my Life;
And Heaven grant I may no longer live,
Than I c • n t • ſt the Joys which Wine do's give.

sp.stage: A claſh of Swords. Sir Will. cries Murder. Coll. and Cla, Bell, and Em. croſs the Stage.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Haſte, my Faireſt, and let us tye that Knot, which nought but Death can loſe.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p:
Certainly, I heard Sir William's Voice cry [Ent. Sir Will.].
〈◊〉 . What's the Matter Sir William? Where's my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: E • f • eble me if I know; you had beſt ſend after her 〈◊〉 , or ſhe'll be married to Manly, who drew upon me; and i • I had •• t • uitted her, he had run me quite thro' the Body, impair my V • g • r.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p:
This was her Project of going on foot, ſhe wou'd not have 〈…〉 , under pretence of Notice being taken, forſooth; and
your Perſwaſion made me go before to get the Parſon ready. Od's fleſh, had I been there, this had not happen'd, old as I am, they ſhou • d not have eſcap • d ſo eaſily. Z' •• ath l • t a Man take your Miſtreſs from you In my Conſcience, young F • llows are ſo rotten now a-days, they are afraid of every S • uffle, l • ſt they drop in pieces. Zounds, I cou'd curſe the Minute I got this Baſtard, to think what a Fortune ſhe has loſt. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Do you take my Breeding to have been at a Bear-garden, Sir, or in Bedl • m, to endanger my Life for your Daughter. No, let her go, I'd marry an Ac • reſs ſooner, and have more Hopes of her Virtue.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Mr. Di • ty Crown? Adod, I cou'd find in my heart to daſh the Powder out of your Whores Hair for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Your Age protects you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Well, if I don • t ſit the Baggage, I'm miſtaken, Egad, I'll marry Toper's Niece immediately. [Enter Toper]
Mr. Toper, you came luckily; I am reſolv'd to marry your Couſin this Moment. N • y I • ll ſettle all I have upon her. I'll hamper my Daughter, I'll warrant her.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I came to inform you Sir, that I ſaw Coll. Manly and your Daughter enter the Church; the Parſon met them at the Door, and I'm much afraid they will be married before you can get to 'em.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Let her marry and be pox't, I • ll not give her a Farthing, I am reſolv • d. Let her go Soldiering with her Huſband, and carry his Knap-ſack, like a Trull as ſhe is. If there be any Favour or Intereſt to be • ad in an Engliſh Parliament, I • ll have the Parſon turn'd out of his place, for a J • co • ite that coupled them.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I have a Friend of mine at the Roſe, juſt come from Oxford, If you pleaſe Mr. Ca • e • ul, I'll fetch him, and you may be marry'd in your own Houſe.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: With all my heart. Adod, methinks I'm briſk and young again. This Auda • ious Wench▪
sp.l: My Blood boils high, and all my Spirits move.
Revenge gives Strength to Age as much as Love.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Well, my deareſt Ann, I think my ſelf the happieſt Man alive ſince I eſpous'd thee: I have ſettl • d my whole Eſtate upon thee, which, with this Kiſs I do confirm to thee again.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Pray forbear Sir—

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: How Wife! Refuſe to kiſs me?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Yes, except a ſweeter Air came from you—Faugh, you have turn'd my Stomach; I wonder you can aſk me, knowing your Lungs are periſh'd.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mercy upon me; Why, what have I married!—

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Here, Where are my Servants. [Ent. a Maid] Run to the Exchange, Fetch me a French Night-gown, and French Head; Set my Dreſſing-table in order, Do you hear? Let my Paint, Powder, and Patches be ready.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh lord! Paint, Powder, and Patches; Why, Hark y' Miſtreſs, Are you not a Quaker?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: No Sir, I only made uſe of that Diſguiſe to catch you in, but you have Money enough to equip me after the Faſhion, and that was the only Motive of my Sanctity.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! undone, undone!

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Look you Sir, I ſhall never endure your Converſation, I muſt have two Beds, two Chambers, and two Tables, it was an Article of our Agreement, you know, that I ſhou'd live retir'd—That is a-part Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A curſe on that Agreement—But hark y' Wife, you are not in Earneſt ſure?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: In earneſt, Why, Do you think I jeaſt with Age?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: And you won't Bed with me?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Did ever Man of your Hairs aſk ſuch Queſtions? I vow I bluſh at your Unreaſonableneſs.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: O Monſtrous!—

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Is it fit I ſhou'd be bury'd? For to Bed with you were a direct Emblem of my going to my Grave!

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! Where is this Rogue, this Toper? What damn'd Succu • us has he topt upon me?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: I'll have your Fict •• e ſ • t in my Wedding Ring, to put me in Mind of Mortality; Do you think I • ll come within your winding Sheets! For what, to hear you 〈◊〉 art all night, and in the Morning find half my Huſband on the Hangings—

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: I am married.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Pray why did you marry? In my Conſcience, you're as youthful as a Coffin, and as hot as the ſultry Winter that froze over the Thames; they ſay the Hard Time did begin from you. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! I am made the Curſe of all Mankind! O Patience! Patience!

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Your Humors comes froſt from you, and your Noſe has Iſicles in Luna

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Hark y' Miſtreſs, you that have a Feaver and Dog-days in your Blood; if you knew this, why did you marry me?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: That your experienc'd Aches, that have felt Springs and Falls theſe Forty Years, ſhou'd aſk ſuch a Queſtion, as if I could not find Friends to ſupply your cold Defects; Do you think a Young Woman high in her Blood!—

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: And hot as Goats and Marmoſets. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Apt to take ſlame, at any Temptation.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: And kindle at the Picture of a Man. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Wou'd w • d Duſt and Aſhes, unleſs ſhe were—

sp.speaker: Caref
sp.p: Crack'd, try'd, or broken up ha!

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Right Sir, or lack'd a Cloak.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Miſchief, and Hell, was there none to make your Cloak but me!

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Not ſo well lin'd Sir, Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! You ſtaid for a wealthy Cuckold, did you?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Your tame Beaſts ſhould have guilded Horns!—Beſides Sir, I thought your Age wou'd wink at ſtolen Helps, if I took Comfort from abroad.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, You ſhall have Comſomſort—I'll deliver Letters for you, or hold the Door!—

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: No Sir, I • ll not give you that Trouble, I'll have a Maid ſhall do that— [Making a Courteſie.]

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh Impudence, unheard of Impudence!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: But, Sir. I look your Coffers ſhou'd maintain me at my Rate.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: How's that, pray?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Why like a Lady; I muſt have you Knighted, for I don't like Miſtriſs.—My Lady, wou'd ſound better.

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: Yes,—I ſhall riſe to Honour.— [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I muſt have ſix Horſes in my Coach, ſom are ſit for thoſe that have a Charge of Children, you and I ſhall never have any.

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: If we have, all Middleſex will be their Fathers.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p:
I'll have four Foot-Men, and this Houſe clear'd of all this Old Lumber, and 〈◊〉
• ainſcotted, and lin'd with Looking-Glaſs, have 〈…〉 , and China.

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: Mercy upon me. 〈◊〉 ye, Miſtriſs, you told me you lov'd Retirement, hated Viſits, and Bargain • d for Hours of Devotion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Right, Sir, but what Woman ſpeaks Truth before ſhe's Married?

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: Politickly Anſwer'd, and like one perfect in the ſinning Trade.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Well, Sir, don't diſcompoſe your ſelf, 'twill ſignify nothing, I'll in and examin your Jewels, chuſe ſome for every Day, and ſome for Maſques and Balls.

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: The Devil go with you: Oh that I had my Daughter again! Two Days more of this, and I ſhall grow Mad, or to Redeem my ſelf, daſh out my Brains.

div.stage: Enter on one ſide, the Coll. Clarinda, and Em. on the other, Bell and Toper.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: We have done your Buſineſs, Collonel, Bellemin here has tack'd 'em together.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I Canted out the Form of Matrimony as gravely as if I had taken my Degree at Edinborrough.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: And how does it take?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Oh! Admirably Well, I liſten'd a while, and ſound ſhe manag'd it rarely.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: She'll drive my Father out of his Wits.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Well, Captain, you'll obſerve what I told you, I'll follow you with another Project, I'll warrant you, will give the Old Fellow enough of Matrimony; Collonel, do you be ready when I call, to come in, do you hear? I fancy they are in ſuch Confuſion that it would be no hard Matter for all of you to get into the Houſe unſeen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: We'll endeavour it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But hark ye, Madam, there's ſomething more to be ſaid, before you and I part; Have you the Conſcience to let your Friend launch into the Sea of Matrimony alone?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: To chuſe, Sir, for if the Voyage prove Dang •••• , on at a time is enough to be loſt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Would you have her Surrender upon the firſt Summons, Captain? You muſt expect ſome Fateague in Love, as well as War, the little diſquiet of Hopes and Fears, do but enhan •• the Value of a Miſtriſs when gain'd; Soldiers and Knight Erra ••…
〈◊〉 Court Danger and Deſpiſe an Enterpriſe that had no Difficulty 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, if I had but the Hopes of a Carnival 〈◊〉 this Lent, 'twould be a ſufficient Recompence, but Exp •• lation and Uncertainty, is the worſt Food in the World for a Fellow of my Conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Come, Madam, be Generous, you cannot have an Honeſter Fellow, I'll ſay that for him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Look ye there, Madam, he'll Vouch for me, if you don't think my own Word ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I ſhall truſt no Bodies Judgment but my own, and that tells me, you are too much a Libertine for a Huſband; why you have not the leaſt Reſemblence of a Lover.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Reſemblance! Why I am a perfect Skeleton, do but ſee how pale and wan I look! My Taylor ſhall Swear I am fall'n away ſix Inches in the Waſt, ſince this Day ſeven Night, and if theſe be no Signs of being in Love, the Devil's in't.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Very violent Symptoms truly.—Have you any more of them, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Thouſand; do but feel here the Palpation of my Heart, the Irregularity of my Pulſe, the Immotion of my Brain.—In ſhort, my whole Frame's diſorder'd, and without immediate Help, I'm a Dead Man.—I'm quite out of Breath, I hope ſhe won't put me to the expence of any more lyes, for certainly I have told enough to deſerve any one Woman in Chriſtendom. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman; Well, if your Diſtemper continues, I'll conſult my Pillow for a Remedy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Take me with you to that Study, Madam, the ſight of me there, will very much improve your Underſtanding. [Embracing her.]

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Come, I hope to ſee thee Bleſt as I am.—And now my Faireſt, my whole Study ſhall be to make you Happy. [To Clarinda.]

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Madam, you had as good give me my Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Not till I ſee the event of your Plot upon my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Come, come, ſhe's thine Boy.

l.hi: For tho'-at firſt the Sex o're-ſhoot, deny.
Preſs 'em but home, and they will all comply.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! What ſhall I do?—Well thou'rt right enough ſerv'd, old Boy—Eh—Pox of thy old doating Head [beats his Head.] Thou muſt Marry for Revenge, muſt thou—I am reveng'd with a Witneſs—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant, I come Sir, to do you a piece of Service, if it be not too late; I heard juſt now, that one Toper had lodg'd a Woman, under pretence of a Couſin, in your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! I'm become the Town-talk already—Well Sir, and what then?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She's a common Strumpit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref
sp.p: How Sir! Have a care what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll prove it Sir, ſhe's of known Practice, the Cloaths ſhe wears are but her Quarters Sins—She has no Lining but what ſhe firſt offends for.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! I ſweat, I ſweat.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe has known Men of all Nations, and lain in by two Parts of the Map, Africa and America.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What ail you Sir, Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh undone! undone! I am married Sir

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay then, Heaven help you—Why wou'd you truſt Toper, the debaucheſt Fellow in Town; ſhe was once his Miſtreſs; Money falling ſhort, I ſuppoſe, he has topt her upon you, and is 〈◊〉 be maintain'd out of your Bags.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! I have ſetl'd all I have in the World upon her, that damn'd Raſcal. Oh that I cou'd ſee him ſtretch'd upon a Rack now, I'd give a thouſand Pound for every Stretch that ſhou'd enlarge the Rogue thro' all his Joynts; that ſhou'd but ſhow him Hell, and then recall his fleeting Soul, and give him ſtrength to endure his Torment often. I'd have him as long a dying as a chop'd Eel.
sp.stage: [Enter two Footmen bearing in a Frame of a Picture, with a Curtain before it.]
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My Lady has ſent your Wife a Preſent Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Who is your Lady?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My Lady Manlove.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Pray what is it?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A Picture for her Bed-chamber, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: For her Bed-chamber? There are but one ſort of Pictures will pleaſe my Wife there—Pray draw back the Curtain.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My Lady charg'd that none ſhou'd ſee it but your Wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Say you ſo Sir; but I will ſee it. [Draws the Curtain, and Toper comes out of the Frame.] Hell! and Damnation! Are you there, Bawd, Pander, Sirrah, I'll cut your Ears off.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold Sir, I muſt prevent your running into ſarther Miſchief; if you kill him the Law purſues you.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: The Law, who wou'd ſcruple Hanging to be reveng'd on ſuch a Dog—Sirrah, you are a Villain—

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Sir, you are rude, and wou'd be beaten; can't a Man come in private, on Buſineſs to your Wife, but you muſt be inquiſitive—

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Why this is beyond Example; Why do you hold me Sir? Z'death, I ſhall be Cuckolded before my face!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ho! Are you come? I thought your Huſband, to keep you chaſt, had ſet a Guard of Eunuchs over you, or ſhut you up in a Room, where no Male Beaſt is pictur'd, leſt the ſight of ought that cou'd beget, ſhou'd ſtir Deſires, for I find he is as Jealous already as an Italian.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: I wonder Sir, who licens'd you to pry, or ſpy out my Friends that come to me in private; it wou'd be more to your Reputation to truſt to my Management, than to be peeping; but it ſhows your unbred Curioſity, which I ſhall correct.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Zounds! This is beyond the Suffering of a Saint; let me go, and I'll ſlit her Noſe—Thou Woman double ſtampt.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: You'll dare to break up Letters ſhortly, and examine my Taylor when he brings home my Gown, leſt there be a Man in't. I'll have you to know Sir, I'll have whom I pleaſe, and when I pleaſe, and in what Diſguiſe Ipleaſe, and not have your ſore Eyes ſo ſawcy to peep, as if by Prevention, you meant to kill a Baſiliſk.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mercy on me! I ſ • all loſe my Underſtanderſtanding.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Couſin Topez, I'll ſetch you the Hundred Pound immediately.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A hundred Pound! Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I vow Sir, I am very much concern'd at your Misfortune, if I was in your place, I'd take my Daughter home; the Collonel is a Man of Honour, and will at leaſt ſecure you from ſuch Affronts as theſe.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Ah poor Girl! But I have not a Farthing to give her—This 〈◊〉 Woman has got all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Suppoſe Sir, I cou'd contrive a way to null your Marriage, Wou'd you forgive your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Caref,
sp.p: With all my Soul.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: What wou'd you give for ſuch a Project, Ha?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: As much as I'd give to ſee you hang'd—Which is all I am worth—

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Well, you wou'd forgive me too, wou'd you not?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Ay, tho' thou hadſt murder'd my Father, and debauch'd my Mother.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Say you ſo Sir—Well, I will be with you in an inſtant.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: But which way will you do it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why you have not Conſummated yet, have you?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: No, thank Heaven.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, then take you no Care; you'll give your Daughter the ſame Fortune you deſign'd for the Fop Knight?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Ay, that I will, and 500 l. more.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come in Lovers, the Scene's chang'd.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Your Bleſſing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And with it, your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: You have it, provided I get unmarried again.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We'll now call for your Lady; Oh, here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Zounds, I Tremble at the Sight of her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: You ſhan't need Sir, for my Fury is over: I wiſh you Joy, Madam, and Sir I here reſign you up your Settlement again.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: How's this? Ha, pray unfold this Myſtery.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Why, Sir, this is Mrs. Pl • twell, your Neighbour, who only put on this Diſguiſe to be Serviceable to your Daughter—This honeſt Gentleman here, was the Parſon that Coupled you.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Now Sir. I think, I have kept my Word with y •• .

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p:
Why, truly Sir, being •• th to 〈◊〉 this 〈…〉 thrown 〈…〉 h • d the Pro • p • ct • f ſ •• h a Worthy 〈…〉 Coll • n • l 〈…〉 to 〈◊〉 you 〈◊〉 your Reaſon, and I don't 〈…〉 own I have done you a piece of Service, in for • ing yo •
〈…〉 Family, and in his 〈◊〉 receiv'd 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Tis now Madam, my 〈…〉 my 〈…〉 for this 〈…〉 p • ay, which way I 〈◊〉 be Grate • ul.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: If I 〈◊〉 done 〈…〉 R • wards it ſelf; and if Mr. 〈…〉 be over-paid.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: With all my Heart. I 〈…〉 Frolick was a pretty Frolick—Now 'tis over.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I heard you was Married, Mr. Careful, I wiſh you Joy.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, Sir William, 'tis my Daughter that is Married.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha, the Collonel Married to my Miſireſs. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir William, I deſire all Quar • els between you and I may be Cancel'd.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray include me in that Treaty too, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Here has been ſtrange juggling, Sir William, I have been Trick'd out of my Conſent, I hope you'll Pardon me too.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I▪m in ſuch Confuſion, that I know not what to ſay, but I muſt ſhow 〈◊〉 my Soul's above an Affront, and that nothing can diſorder the Serenity of my Temper. [Aſide.] Ay, we are all Friends, Gentlemen, and I forgive the Lady too, for ſhe has done more honeſtly by me than moſt Women wou'd, ſhe has Married the Man ſhe lik'd, tho' 'tis the Faſhion to take the Rich Huſband they don't like, and make a Friend of the Man they do.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: One thing I deſire you'd make clear to me, Madam, which is, Why did you give me Encouragment by your Woman?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I give you Encouragment by my Woman? What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I beg your 〈◊〉 . Madam, his Gold prevail'd upon me, and I thought what I ſ •• d would ſignify nothing, I hope you will forgive me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Never: Our of my Doors, I ſuppoſe thro' your managment, Ogle was ſo Familiar with me too.—Out of my Sight.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Indeed, my Dear, I cannot Interceed in her behalf, ſince thro' her means my firſt Suſpicion came, that made us both uneaſy; but as to Ogle, I ſufficiently Reveng'd your Quarrel, for I'll engage he never ſets up for a Beau again.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Confound your whole Sex, you're all not worth a Gentleman's Anger; I'll to my Lodgings, and ſend for the Muſick, and think no more of you nor Matrimony; if I do, I'll give 'em leave to ram me into a Hautboy and blow me out at the Holes; Impair my vigour.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Madam, What ſay you? Have you a mind to ſee me ſwing to Elizium in my Garters, and hear me ſung about in a Ballad to a doleful new Tune, call'd, The Gentleman's Farewell to his unkind Lady—Or will you take Pity on me?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Well, Sir, to prevent ſuch ſad Diſaſters, I don't care if I give you my Hand, and as you deſerve, my Heart ſhall follow.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, give me but the Body, and I'll warrant you I'll get the reſt.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Hey day! What a Wedding chopt up there too! Well, I never ſhall believe common Report again, That all Women are Jacobites, ſince I find them ſo ready to Reward the Soldiers Service to the Nation with their Perſons and Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I wiſh every Brave Man was Rewarded according to his Merit, I'm certain Captain Bellmein deſerves more than I can give him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Don't Compliment your Huſband, Madam, you don't know half my Deſerts yet.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Brave Boys, brave Boys.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir here's the Muſick without, come to Congratulate your Marriage.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Bid 'em come in, we'll have a Dance.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I wiſh you Joy if there can be any ſuch thing in a Wife; but for my part, it ſhall always be my Maxim not to part with my Liberty, till I can't help it; What Bird wou'd be confin'd to a Cage, when it can ſkip from Tree to Tree? Collonel, I'll come and take a Bottle with you by and by.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Madam, you deſerve our beſt Thanks for this exemplary piece of Juſtice, and be aſſured, you have laid an eternal Obligation on me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I am pleas'd that I have done you Service, and henceforth ſhall Devote my ſelf to Virtue, and I hope Heaven will Pardon the Follies of my paſt Life.

l.hi: Bleſt in my Love, I Envy no Man's Fate,
Content alone, is the true happy State.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Virtue thou ſhining Jewel of my Sex—Thou precious Thing that none knows how to Value as they ought, while they Enjoy it, but like Spend-thrift Heirs, when they have waſted all their Store, wou'd give the World they cou'd retrieve their loſt Eſtate: Therefore beware, you happy Maids, how you liſten to the deluding Tongues of Men, 'tis only they have Power to betray you.

l.hi: Oh happy ſhe, that can ſecurely ſay
Folly be gone, I have no mind to Play,
My Fame is Clear, I have not Sinn'd to Day.

lg.l: YOƲ ſee, Gallants, 't has been our Poets Care
To ſhew what Beaux in their Perfection are,
By Nature Cowards, foo • iſh, uſele • s fools,
Made Men by Tay • ors, and by Women, Fools:
A F • ckle, Falſe, a Singing, Dancing Crew,
Nay now we hear they've Smiling Maſters too;
Juſt now a Frenchman in the Dreſſing Room,
From Teaching of a Beau to Smile, was come,
He ſhew'd five G • i • ea • .—War'nt he rarely paid,
Thus all the World by Smiles are once betray'd;
The States Man Smiles on them he wou'd Undo,
The Courtier's Smi • es are very ſeldom True,
The Lovers Smiles too many do believe,
And Women Smile on them they wou'd Deceive;
When Trades-Men Smile, they ſafely Cheat with Eaſe,
And Smiling Lawyers never fail of Fees.—
The Doctor's Look the Patient's Pain beguiles,
The Sick Man lives. if the Phyſician Smiles:
Thus Smiles with Intereſt hand in hand do go,
He ſureſt Strikes, that Smiling gives the Blow;
Poets, with us, this Proverb do Defy,
We live by Smiles, for if you Frown we die.
To Pleaſe you then ſhall be our chief Endeavour,
And all we ask, is but your Smiles for Ever.
Hold—I forget, The Author bid me ſay,
She humbly begs Protection for her Play:
'Tis Yours—She Dedicates, it to you all,
And ſure you're too Gen'rous, to let it fall;
She hopes the Ladies will her Cauſe Maintain,
Since Virtue here has been her only Aim.
The Beaux, ſhe thinks, won't fail to do her Right,
Since here they're taught with ſafety how to Fight.
She's ſure of Favour from the Men of War,
A Soldier is her Darling Character;
To fear their M • rm • rs then wou'd be abſurd,
They only Mutiny when not Prefer'd:
But • et, I ſee, ſhe does your Fury dread,
And like a Priſoner, ſtands with fear half Dead,
While you are Judges, do her Sentence give,
〈◊〉 you're not pleat'd, ſhe ſays ſhe cannot live.
Let my Petition then for once prevail,
And let your gen'rous Claps her Pardon Seal.
